Behind The Wire

A Graphic Portrait Of Life In Detention

Thousands of people were held in immigration detention centres across Australia between October 2009 and May 2011. The majority of them, after “processing”, would be found to be refugees and granted asylum in Australia. Some are still in detention.

Serco, the multinational company that managed Australia’s 27 detention facilities during this period, was required to log every ”incident” — a skinned knee, a birth, an electricity failure, a person found dead from hanging.

Here are those records.

Highlight:

All incidents
All Facilities
Reset

This is part of our series on asylum seekers in detention View all related stories

ADOPT AN INCIDENT

There is a bigger story behind each of these squares. The government has detailed reports for each of the incidents summarised here. The reports hold much more detail about the event — including who was involved and what happened to the person being detained.

To get the government to release these reports, we need your help.

We’re calling on our audience to “adopt an incident”, using the Freedom of Information Act. So if you see an incident that you think needs further investigation, or that should be made public, we are asking you to request it.

Lodging a request for a detailed incident report is easy and free. Click on a square and find the “adopt an incident” link. This will take you to the Right To Know site, where you will be led through your request; as much as possible, the form will be automatically record details of the incident and relevant language.

    tour
    ×

    Each square represents a single ‘incident report’ logged by Serco, the company that manages detention centres in Australia.

    These reports, gathered via numerous Freedom of Information requests by the journalists from detentionlogs.com.au, present a stark view from inside these centres.

    While not a full picture of the life of a detainee, viewed together these incident logs (reproduced here exactly as they appear in the reports, including spelling errors) help show the extremes of what goes on in Australia’s detention centres.

    Next
    Previous
    Perth IDC
    Intercom system down
    1/11/2010 6:30 pm

    Each event summary is logged in the same dry, bureaucratic language, but the incidents range from the banal...

    Next
    Previous
    Northern IDC
    Client self harmed by suturing his lips.
    22/4/2011 10:55 am

    ...to the disturbing, providing a glimpse into the extremes of daily life in detention.

    Rather than cherry-pick incidents we’ve chosen to include them all to highlight this contrast.

    Next
    Previous

    This interactive highlights selected

    • detention-centre openings
    • boat-related incidents
    • media reports
    • policy announcements
    Next
    Previous

    We’re also asking our audience to highlight, or ‘flag’, those incidents which they feel others need to see.

    The more often an incident is ‘flagged’ the brighter its square appears. Flagged incidents can also be shared with others.

    We hope that this audience-driven highlighting will aid others in discovering the most disturbing incidents for themselves.

    Next
    Previous

    There are more than 7,000 incident reports here. For most, a more detailed report exists but the government has not made those public.

    So, we’ve made it easy for anyone to make a Freedom of Information request and discover the backstory, via a link on each report.
